unit.title: Bohr
unit.definition: The smallest possible orbital radius for an electron in hydrogen in the Bohr model.
unit.description: Note that the definition of Bohr radius does not include the effect of reduced mass, and so it is not precisely equal to the orbital radius of the electron in a hydrogen atom in the more physical model where reduced mass is included. This is done for convenience: the Bohr radius as defined above appears in equations relating to atoms other than hydrogen, where the reduced mass correction is different. If the definition of Bohr radius included the reduced mass of hydrogen, it would be necessary to include a more complex adjustment in equations relating to other atoms.

unit.title: Angstrom
unit.description: The angstrom is named after the Swedish physicist Anders Jonas Angstrom (1814â€“1874), one of the founders of spectroscopy, after his spectrum chart of solar radiation in the electromagnetic spectrum on the order of multiples of one ten-millionth of a millimetre, or 1E-10 metres.

unit.title: Electron mass
unit.definition: Mass of a single electron in vacuum.

unit.title: Unified Atomic Mass Unit
unit.definition: 1/12 of the mass of one atom of carbon-12.
unit.description: The unit is convenient because one hydrogen atom has a mass of approximately 1 amu, and more generally an atom or molecule that contains n protons and neutrons will have a mass approximately equal to n amu. (The reason is that a carbon-12 atom contains 6 protons, 6 neutrons and 6 electrons, with the protons and neutrons having about the same mass and the electron mass being negligible in comparison.) This is only a rough approximation however, since it does not account for the mass contained in the binding energy of an atom's nucleus; this binding energy mass is not a fixed fraction of an atom's total mass.

unit.title: Elementary charge
unit.definition: Magnitude of the charge of a single electron (or positron) in vacuum.
unit.description: The electron is one of a class of subatomic particles called leptons which are believed to be fundamental particles (that is, they cannot be broken down into smaller constituent parts). The word "particle" is somewhat misleading however, because quantum mechanics shows that electrons also behave like a wave, e.g. in the double-slit experiment; this is called wave-particle duality.

unit.title: Hartree
unit.definition: Twice the absolute value of the binding energy of the electron in the ground state of the hydrogen atom.
